p: The positively charged polysaccharide chitosan is essentially composed of β-(1,4)-linked glucosamine units (2-amino-2-deoxy-β-d-glucopyranose) together with some proportion of N-acetylglucosamine units (2-acetamino-2-deoxy-β-d-glucopyranose), and prepared by partial deacetylation of the natural polymer chitin (Anitha et al., 2014). Chitosan is biocompatible, degradable and has been tested for biomedical applications ranging from wound dressing, drug delivery to tissue engineering (Lopez-Leon et al., 2005; Anitha et al., 2014). It is typically dissolved in acidic media (e.g., acetic acid) due to the existence of amine groups and high crystallinity.
